conclusion: To determine the time during which there is an induced current in the square conductor frame as it moves through the magnetic field, we need to analyze the motion and the conditions under which electromagnetic induction occurs.
The square conductor frame with side length \( l \) is moving uniformly with speed \( v \) from left to right through a magnetic field of width \( d \). The frame starts outside the magnetic field.

An induced current occurs when the frame is partially or fully inside the magnetic field, as the magnetic flux through the loop changes. This occurs when the frame enters and exits the magnetic field.

premise: The frame starts to enter the magnetic field when its leftmost edge aligns with the left boundary of the magnetic field.
conclusion: The frame fully enters the magnetic field when its entire side length \( l \) is within the magnetic field.

premise: The frame fully enters the magnetic field when its entire side length \( l \) is within the magnetic field.
conclusion: The time taken for the left side of the frame to move distance \( l \) into the magnetic field is \( \frac{l}{v} \).

premise: From the moment the leftmost edge enters until the rightmost edge exits the entry boundary, there is a change in flux.
Once the frame is fully inside the magnetic field, the entire frame is within the field, and no change in flux occurs until it starts to exit.
conclusion: This state lasts until the leftmost edge of the frame reaches the right boundary of the magnetic field.

premise: The frame starts to exit when the leftmost edge aligns with the right boundary of the magnetic field.
conclusion: It fully exits when its entire side length \( l \) is out of the magnetic field.

premise: It fully exits when its entire side length \( l \) is out of the magnetic field.
conclusion: The time taken for the left side of the frame to move distance \( l \) out of the magnetic field is \( \frac{l}{v} \).

premise: From the moment the leftmost edge starts exiting until the rightmost edge fully exits, there is a change in flux.
The total time during which the frame experiences a change in magnetic flux (and thus an induced current) is the sum of the time taken for entry and exit phases.
conclusion: The time for the frame to move through the width \( d \) of the magnetic field is \( \frac{d}{v} \).

premise: The total duration of induced current is the time from when the leftmost edge enters the field to when the rightmost edge exits the field.
conclusion: This includes the entry time \( \frac{l}{v} \), the transit time \( \frac{d}{v} \), and the exit time \( \frac{l}{v} \).

premise: Therefore, the total time \( t \) is: \[ t = \ rac{l}{v} + \ rac{d}{v}
